pullRequest.body:
In this proof, we abuse the definition of `Matrix` by applying matrices. This is why we needed to parenthesize `Fintype.sum_apply` to convince `simp` to apply it even though the type is `Matrix m n Œ±`, not `m ‚Üí _`.

Turns out there's a version of `Fintype.sum_apply` specialized to matrices: `Matrix.sum_apply`.

Close #12717


---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [4c2de57712](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18968/commits/4c2de5771287c8f02b5facd4ef79a4be6b20846a)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

No declarations were harmed in the making of this PR! üêô
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.
FYI this actually passes CI. @adomani explained that the CI error is caused to a script version differing between branches
Is that abuse? Isn't that how matrices are designed to be used?

It is abuse to the extent that `Matrix m n Œ±` is not synteq to `m ‚Üí n ‚Üí Œ±`. So simp doesn't fire lemmas about `m ‚Üí n ‚Üí Œ±` on a subexpression of type `Matrix m n Œ±`. This is precisely what's happening below.

In fact, I was surprised to see that `Matrix` doesn't have a `FunLike` instance. That would be the natural solution. But I now remember that @eric-wieser said that Lean would more eagerly unfold `Matrix m n Œ±` to check whether it's a function type than it would try synthesizing a `DFunLike` instance.
I think the comment should stay next to the tactic in question, not next to the proof.

This is not abuse of `Matrix`, this is how it is intended to be used. Of course, it might be abuse of Lean itself... (vs using a one-field structure).

I think the motivation applies to the existence of `Matrix.add_apply` etc too; but it's interesting that somehow the `(some_lemma)` syntax makes things work.
What do you want me to write, concretely?
I think what I actually want you to do is write `Matrix.sum_apply`, and use that lemma here instead of `Fintype.sum_apply`.
I was hoping for a better fix, but okay

> I was hoping for a better fix, but okay

You could extend the comments around `Matrix.add_apply` etc if you want to push for that.

nodes.title: Porting note: `simp` doesn't apply `simp` lemma unless parenthesized

pullRequest.title: chore: deal with "`simp` doesn't apply `simp` lemma unless parenthesized" porting notes
